Relations between finite sets can be desribed in a more computationally friendly way by their tabulation as matrices. In particular, we shall see in § that an {\mathopen {}\left (m\times n\right )\mathclose {}}-matrix over the boolean semiring is precisely the same thing as a relation from {\mathopen {}\left [m\right ]\mathclose {}} to {\mathopen {}\left [n\right ]\mathclose {}}, where {\mathopen {}\left [l\right ]\mathclose {}}={\mathopen {}\left \{i\mid 0\leq i < l\right \}\mathclose {}} is the set of natural numbers strictly smaller than l. Then we will see that relational composition is, under this correspondence, the same as matrix multiplication.

For natural numbers m and n, an {\mathopen {}\left (m\times n\right )\mathclose {}}-matrix over a semiring {\mathopen {}\left (S,0,\oplus ,1,\odot \right )\mathclose {}} is given by entries M_{i,j}\in S for all i\in {\mathopen {}\left [m\right ]\mathclose {}} and j\in {\mathopen {}\left [n\right ]\mathclose {}}. We will write \mathrm {Mat}_{S}{\mathopen {}\left (m,n\right )\mathclose {}} for the set of {\mathopen {}\left (m\times n\right )\mathclose {}}-matrices.

{\mathopen {}\left (m\times n\right )\mathclose {}}-matrices can be depicted in tables or grids with rows in the first dimension and columns in the second dimension. fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Associativity and unit laws of matrix products

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The product of matrices is associative and has the identity matrix as neutral element.

For one unit law, we fix M\in \mathrm {Mat}_{S}{\mathopen {}\left (m,n\right )\mathclose {}} and recall the definition of the identity matrix to check that M\otimes I^m = M.

Unfolding the definition of I^m_{i,j} as given in Definition , we see that the iterated sum above expands to m-1 copies of 0\odot M_{k,j} for various k \not = i and one copy of 1\odot M_{i,j}. Thus, we conclude that M\otimes I^m_{i,j} = M_{i,j} using the absorption and unit laws for multiplication as well as the unit laws for addition in S.

A (binary) relation R from a set A to a set B, written R\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } B or R\in \mathrm {Rel}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} is defined to be a subset R\subseteq A\times B. We shall typically write a\mathrel {R}b for {\mathopen {}\left (a,b\right )\mathclose {}}\in R. More generally, a relation between multiple sets {\mathopen {}\left (A_i\right )\mathclose {}}_{i\in I} is defined to be a subset of the cartesian product \prod _{i\in I} A_i.
